solution_line_template: Since the ratio of apples to oranges is 3:1, that means for every {apples_ratio_part} apples there is {oranges_ratio_part} orange. The size of this group is therefore {apples_ratio_part}+{oranges_ratio_part}=<<{apples_ratio_part}+{oranges_ratio_part}={group_size}>>{group_size}.

We then divide this group size into the total amount of fruit the basket is holding at this time, which is {total_fruit}. This means there are {total_fruit}/{group_size}=<<{total_fruit}/{group_size}={number_of_groups}>>{number_of_groups} of these groups in total.

Since there are {number_of_groups} of these groups in total, that means there are {number_of_groups}*{oranges_ratio_part}=<<{number_of_groups}*{oranges_ratio_part}={oranges_count}>>{oranges_count} oranges in the basket.
